Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RAPID: re-wiring of montane pollination networks under severe drought stress
Award.AbstractNarration:
A severe drought is expected in the western Rockies in 2018, following the second-lowest snowpack on record the preceding winter. The drought will dramatically alter which species are present in the ecosystems of the Rockies and their relative abundances. The drought thus presents an unusual opportunity to study how pollination networks (the connections between interacting pollinator and plant species) are affected by disturbances. This is important given that extreme environmental events are expected to become increasingly common and that pollination is critically important for the maintenance of both wild plant populations and the productivity and security of many agricultural crops. Specifically, this project is focused on 1) how species in ecosystems can form new connections to other species after disturbances; 2) how new connections can be predicted even following major disturbance; and 3) the implications of new patterns of plant-pollinator relationships for understanding ecosystem-level responses to disturbance. This work will contribute to better understanding of how networks (including other ecological networks, and other network types such as economic, engineered, and social networks) respond to disturbances, particularly in terms of the formation of new connections.

This project will use existing plant-pollinator network field data from non-drought years (2016 and 2017) to build and test mechanism-focused models of network structure, based on plant and pollinator abundances, competition between pollinators for flowers, and data on plant and pollinator physical traits (such as body size). Model predictions will be compared with field data from the severe drought year (2018) in which it is anticipated that there will be a strong reduction in which species are present (for example, many long-lived plant species may not bloom when drought-stressed) as well as substantial changes in relative abundances of flowers and pollinators. In particular, the project will also assess how well this new network model performs relative to existing alternative models (none of which currently perform well in predicting interactions). The researchers will then use models to assess generally how substantial capacity for re-wiring will affect system-level responses to perturbations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was focused on assessing how severe droughts impact plant-pollinator interactions. This work was developed to contribute to understanding how perturbations may impact diverse communities of interacting organisms in nature, which in turn underlie many of the ecosystem functions and services that humans depend on. This project used an ecological networks framework, focused on understanding the structure of connections between plant and pollinator species in ecosystems. This approach leverages network-based studies in other fields, such as computer, neuronal, social, and genetic networks. The project was designed to test the hypothesis that severe drought perturbations in pollination networks will lead to substantial changes in the identities of which species interact. We further hypothesized that network structure in drought years would display lower robustness to coextinction (i.e., how many additional plants or pollinators would be lost if one species were to go extinct from the system), even when compared to a non-drought system with comparable properties (numbers of interactions and numbers of species). 

 

The three specific objectives of our project were: 1) conduct field work at the Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory in Colorado focused on characterizing pollination networks, plant and pollinator species abundances, and trait measurements of plants and pollinators in drought vs. non-drought years; 2) develop models for predicting realized interactions in pollination networks, including under perturbations; and 3) assess the consequences of changes in ecological interactions for system-level robustness to coextinctions.

 

Four highlights of our results include: 1) flower and insect abundances in drought years are much lower than in non-drought years; 2) several novel connections between plants and pollinators were found in drought conditions; 3) several aspects of network structure differ between drought and non-drought years; and 4) networks in drought years show substantially reduced robustness to coextinction relative to non-drought years. The project has resulted in nine papers at the time of report submission that are either published or in review / revision in top journals. This includes published four papers to date, in Ecology Letters, Nature Communications (2x), and The American Naturalist. In addition, we have five other papers in review or revision, specifically three papers in revision and two in review (two in Ecology Letters, as well as Ecology, the American Naturalist, and Oecologia). We have several other manuscripts in advanced stages of preparation and expect another 6-8 papers to result from work on this project.

 

The broader impacts of this work include conservation implications in understanding how climatic variation may impact groups of interacting organisms. Our modeling work developed new approaches to understanding how ecological networks change under perturbations and may be applied in a range of other fields. Our unique multi-year dataset may be utilized for a range of other investigations. This project also provided scientific training to several undergraduates, graduate students, and post-docs, including several from groups traditionally underrepresented in science, and provided training to a faculty member at a primarily undergraduate institution.
